questions.text: A 65-year-old smoker, male presented with painless hematuria. On further investigation he is diagnosed with bladder cancer extending upto the muscle layer. What should be the treatment of choice in this patient? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Radical cystectomy

 

Radical cystectomy is the treatment of choice for a patient with bladder cancer involving the muscle layer.

 

Radical Cystectomy (Option C):

 

  • This is a surgery to remove the entire bladder and possibly nearby tissues and organs. For men, this often includes the prostate and seminal vesicles. For women, the uterus, ovaries, fallopian tubes, and part of the vagina might be removed.
  • It is the treatment of choice for muscle-invasive bladder cancer, meaning the tumor has grown into the muscular wall of the bladder.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Intravesical BCG followed by chemotherapy:

 

  • BCG is a type of immunotherapy where Bacillus Calmette-Guerin (a bacterium similar to the one that causes tuberculosis) is introduced directly into the bladder. This stimulates an immune response against cancer cells.
  • This treatment is typically reserved for non-muscle-invasive bladder cancer or carcinoma in situ (CIS).

 

Option B. Systemic Chemotherapy:

 

  • This might be used before surgery to shrink the tumor or after surgery to kill any remaining cancer cells.
  • Systemic chemotherapy alone is not the primary treatment for muscle-invasive bladder cancer but can be used in conjunction with surgery or other treatments.

 

Option D. Radiotherapy:

 

  • This uses high-energy radiation to kill cancer cells. It might be used as a primary treatment for those who aren't candidates for surgery or combined with chemotherapy as an alternative to surgery.
  • However, the gold standard treatment for muscle-invasive bladder cancer remains radical cystectomy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Radical cystectomy is the treatment of choice for muscle-invasive bladder cancer

questions.text: An image of a perianal disease is shown. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans.  A) Fistula in Ano


The correct diagnosis is Fistula in Ano. A fistula in ano is an abnormal connection between the interior of the anal canal and the perianal skin. It often presents as a recurrent swelling or abscess near the anal verge, which may drain spontaneously. The key clues include the location of the swelling near the anal verge and the history of recurrent discharge, making it characteristic of a fistula in ano.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pilonidal Sinus: A pilonidal sinus is typically found in the upper part of the natal cleft, far from the anal verge, and is associated with hair follicles in the gluteal region. It commonly affects young men with a hairy back and is located above the coccyx, not near the anus. The key distinction is the location; pilonidal sinuses are not found at the anal verge but higher up in the gluteal cleft.

 

 

Option C. Fissure in Ano: A fissure in ano is a linear tear in the lining of the anus, usually caused by trauma or hard stools. It presents with pain during defecation and bright red bleeding but not with a swelling or external opening as seen in fistula in ano. There may be a hypertrophic skin tag covering it (Sentinel pile). Fissures do not have a history of recurrent discharge or a swelling appearance near the anal verge.

 

 

Option D. Hemorrhoids: Hemorrhoids are swollen blood vessels in the rectum or anus and typically present with painless bleeding, itching, and swelling inside the anal canal or at the anal verge. They do not present with the external openings, recurrent abscesses, or discharging sinuses characteristic of fistula in ano.

 

 

Educational Objective:


Fistula in Ano should be considered when there is a history of recurrent swelling, abscess formation, or discharge near the anal verge. It is distinguished from pilonidal sinus by its lower location near the anal canal, as opposed to pilonidal sinuses that occur higher up in the natal cleft.

questions.text: A patient presents with sudden onset of chest pain shooting to the neck and interscapular region. X-ray shows widened mediastinum. BP is 110/90 mmHg in the right upper limb and 160/100 mmHg in the left upper limb. What is the most likely diagnosis?(NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Acute aortic dissection

 

  • Patient with sudden-onset severe chest pain, with a difference in blood pressure between the two limbs, and a widened mediastinum on x-ray suggests a diagnosis of acute aortic dissection.
  • AORTIC DISSECTION is tear in intima of aorta

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute Coronary Syndrome (ACS): ACS includes conditions such as myocardial infarction and unstable angina. These conditions typically present with chest pain but do not usually cause blood pressure discrepancies between limbs or a widened mediastinum.

 

Option B. Acute Pulmonary Embolism: Pulmonary embolism presents with sudden onset dyspnea, pleuritic chest pain, and signs of right heart strain. It does not typically present with blood pressure discrepancies between limbs or a widened mediastinum.

 

Option D. Esophageal Rupture: Esophageal rupture can present with severe chest pain, subcutaneous emphysema, and signs of sepsis. It does not typically present with blood pressure discrepancies between limbs. It may cause mediastinal widening but would more likely present with other signs such as subcutaneous emphysema.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The classic presentation of acute aortic dissection includes sudden severe chest pain radiating to the neck and back, a discrepancy in blood pressure between the limbs, and a widened mediastinum on chest X-ray.
  • Immediate imaging with a CT thoracic angiogram and lowering blood pressure are crucial steps in management.

questions.text: A 45-year-old lady presents to the emergency department with severe abdominal pain. An abdominal ultrasound reveals the presence of multiple gallstones with no evidence of wall thickening. The bile duct (BD) diameter is measured at 12 mm, and serum bilirubin levels are mildly elevated at 0.8. The patient's alkaline phosphatase levels are significantly elevated at 380, and the gamma-glutamyl transferase (GGT) levels are raised by 5 times. What is the next best step in the management of this patient? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) MRCP

 

Given the patient's presentation of multiple gallstones, an enlarged bile duct diameter, and elevated liver enzymes, there is a high suspicion of choledocholithiasis (stones in the common bile duct). An MRCP is the most appropriate initial investigation to visualize and confirm the presence of common bile duct stones without subjecting the patient to an invasive procedure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. ERCP (Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography): ERCP is an invasive procedure that allows both the visualization and treatment of biliary and pancreatic duct abnormalities. While it can be used to diagnose and treat choledocholithiasis, it is generally reserved for therapeutic interventions after the diagnosis has been established, given the risks associated with the procedure.

 

Option C. Endoscopic ultrasound: This technique can be very sensitive for detecting common bile duct stones and other biliary pathologies. However, in the context of a patient with an enlarged bile duct and elevated liver enzymes suggestive of choledocholithiasis, MRCP would be the preferred initial diagnostic tool.

 

Option D. Laparoscopic cholecystectomy: While the patient may ultimately require a cholecystectomy, especially if the gallstones are the cause of her symptoms, it's crucial to first assess and manage any potential common bile duct stones. Directly proceeding to cholecystectomy without addressing potential common bile duct stones could lead to complications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In summary, given the patient's clinical presentation and laboratory findings suggesting the presence of common bile duct stones, an MRCP is the most appropriate initial step to visualize the biliary system and confirm the diagnosis.

questions.text: Heller's operation is performed for: (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Achalasia cardia

 

The most common surgical procedure done for achalasia cardia is laparoscopic Heller myotomy in conjugation with partial fundoplication.

 

Heller's operation is most commonly performed to treat Achalasia cardia. Achalasia is a medical condition characterized by the failure of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES) to relax properly, leading to difficulty in swallowing and the accumulation of food in the esophagus. Heller myotomy involves cutting the muscles of the LES to alleviate the obstruction and improve the passage of food into the stomach.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Carcinoma esophagus: Cancer of the esophagus is typically treated with other approaches such as surgery to remove the tumor, chemotherapy, radiation therapy, or a combination of these treatments.

 

Option C. Esophageal stricture: Esophageal stricture refers to the narrowing of the esophagus, often due to scar tissue formation. Treatment for esophageal strictures may involve dilation procedures or other surgical techniques depending on the underlying cause.

 

Option D. Hypertrophic pyloric stenosis: Treatment for hypertrophic pyloric stenosis typically involves a surgical procedure called Ramsteads pyloromyotomy to alleviate the obstruction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Achalasia cardia, commonly referred to as achalasia, is a medical condition that affects the esophagus, specifically the lower esophageal sphincter (LES) and the muscles of the esophageal wall. This condition is characterized by the following features:

 

  1. Failure of LES Relaxation: In achalasia, the LES, a muscular ring that separates the esophagus from the stomach, does not relax properly during swallowing. Normally, the LES should relax to allow food and liquids to pass into the stomach, but in achalasia, this relaxation is impaired.
  2. Incomplete Emptying of the Esophagus: Due to the dysfunctional LES, the esophagus is unable to empty food and liquids into the stomach efficiently. This leads to a gradual buildup of food and fluids in the esophagus, causing symptoms.
  3. Difficulty in Swallowing: The most prominent symptom of achalasia is dysphagia, which is difficulty in swallowing. Patients often experience a sensation of food getting stuck in the chest while eating and may need to drink fluids or change their body position to help food pass into the stomach.
  4. Regurgitation: As a result of the esophageal emptying problems, patients with achalasia may also experience regurgitation of undigested food, often occurring at night when lying down.
  5. Chest Pain: Some individuals with achalasia may experience chest pain or discomfort, often due to the accumulation of food and fluids in the esophagus.

 

Achalasia is typically diagnosed through tests such as esophageal manometry, which measures the pressure within the esophagus, and barium swallow studies, which show the narrowing of the esophagus and the delayed emptying of contrast material.

 

Treatment options for achalasia include:

 

  • Heller Myotomy: This surgical procedure involves cutting the muscles of the LES to allow for improved passage of food and liquids into the stomach. It is the primary surgical treatment for achalasia.
  • Pneumatic Dilation: In this non-surgical procedure, a balloon is inflated within the LES to stretch and disrupt the muscle fibers, making it easier for food to pass.
  • Botulinum Toxin Injection: Injecting botulinum toxin directly into the LES can help relax the muscle temporarily. However, this treatment may need to be repeated periodically.

 

The choice of treatment depends on various factors, including the patient's age, overall health, and the severity of the condition. Effective management of achalasia can alleviate symptoms and improve the quality of life for individuals with this disorder.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male with a history of intravenous drug use presents to the emergency department with a pulsatile mass in the inguinal region. Imaging studies reveal a pseudoaneurysm involving an artery. What is the most commonly involved artery in pseudoaneurysm formation? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Femoral artery

 

The femoral artery is a common site for pseudoaneurysm formation, especially in individuals with a history of intravenous drug use.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aorta: While pseudoaneurysms can occur in the aorta, they are less common than in peripheral arteries like the femoral artery.

 

Option C. Popliteal artery: Pseudoaneurysms can occur in the popliteal artery, but they are less common than in the femoral artery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A pseudoaneurysm is a pulsatile hematoma that forms when there is a breach in the arterial wall, resulting in the extravasation of blood into the surrounding tissues.
  • The most commonly involved artery in pseudoaneurysm formation is the femoral artery, due to its superficial location and frequent use for arterial access.
  • Pseudoaneurysms can also occur in other arteries, such as the brachial, radial, ulnar, and carotid arteries.
  • Common causes of pseudoaneurysm formation include trauma, iatrogenic injury during medical procedures (e.g., arterial catheterization), and underlying arterial disease (e.g., atherosclerosis).
  • The clinical presentation of a pseudoaneurysm may include a pulsatile mass, pain, tenderness, and signs of bleeding or hematoma formation.
  • The diagnosis of a pseudoaneurysm is confirmed by imaging studies such as ultrasound, CT scan, or angiography.
  • Treatment options for a pseudoaneurysm may include observation, compression, percutaneous thrombin injection, or surgical repair depending on the size, location, and underlying cause of the lesion.
  • MC site of true peripheral aneurysm is however, the popliteal artery.

questions.text: Which of the following incisions is used for Appendicectomy? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Grid iron incision

 

The grid iron incision, also known as the McArthur incision, is the preferred surgical approach for an appendectomy. This incision is made at the McBurney point, which is located one-third of the distance from the anterior superior iliac spine to the umbilicus. The incision is muscle-splitting rather than cutting, which helps in minimizing muscle damage and promotes quicker recovery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Kocher's incision: This is used for open cholecystectomy. It is a right subcostal incision, typically employed for gallbladder surgeries.

 

Option B. Morris incision: This is a flank incision used for accessing the retroperitoneal space, typically for renal surgeries.

 

Option D. Pfannensteil incision: This is a lower abdominal, transverse suprapubic incision often used for gynecological surgeries, such as cesarean sections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The grid iron (McArthur) incision is the standard incision used for appendectomy, made at the McBurney point and characterized by a muscle-splitting approach.

questions.text: Following a stab injury to the chest, the following imaging finding was noted. What is the diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hemothorax

 

In this scenario, the patient has sustained a stab injury to the chest, and an X-ray has been provided as part of the diagnostic process. The X-ray described in the  reveals a white area on the affected side of the lung field.

Hemothorax: A hemothorax occurs when blood accumulates in the pleural cavity. On a chest X-ray, this condition presents as a white-out or opaque area on the affected side due to the fluid (blood) collecting in the pleural space. The clinical findings, such as hypotension (which can result from blood loss), further support this diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pneumothorax: In contrast, a pneumothorax, which is the presence of air in the pleural space, would show up on a chest X-ray as a black area (radiolucency) without lung markings, indicating air in the pleural space. This would not match the white-out appearance seen in the provided X-ray.

 

Option C. Diaphragmatic Rupture: This condition would typically present with air-fluid levels within the chest cavity if abdominal organs have herniated into the thoracic cavity. However, this is not indicated by the described X-ray findings.

 

Option D. Lung Contusion: A lung contusion would appear as a focal area of consolidation (white patch) due to localized bleeding or bruising of the lung tissue, but it would not cause a widespread white-out of the lung field.

 

Thus, the presence of a white-out on the X-ray, along with clinical signs such as hypotension, suggests the correct diagnosis is hemothorax.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A white-out on the chest X-ray after a chest injury, especially with accompanying hypotension, is indicative of a hemothorax, which is the accumulation of blood in the pleural space.

choices.text: Wide local excision with frozen border

questions.text: A 55-year-old farmer presents with an ulcer on his neck, and a biopsy confirms squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) with negative lymph nodes. What is the most appropriate management strategy for this patient? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Wide local excision with radiation 

 

When managing squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) of the skin, especially in areas exposed to high levels of sun, such as the neck, the treatment approach may vary based on the size, depth, and location of the tumor as well as the patient's overall health. 

 

This is often the preferred treatment for SCC with a high risk of recurrence or metastasis. The tumor is excised with a margin of normal tissue, and radiation is used to kill any remaining cancer cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Radiotherapy: This can be used as a primary treatment for SCC, especially if surgery is not possible, but it is more commonly used adjuvantly (following surgery) if there are high-risk features.

 

Option C. Wide local excision with frozen border: This refers to excision with immediate pathological examination (frozen section) to ensure clear margins. This is a good option for ensuring complete removal during surgery, but adjuvant radiation may still be recommended based on the tumor's features.

 

Option D. Skin grafting: This is a reconstructive procedure used after the removal of the tumor if the defect is too large to close primarily. It does not treat the cancer itself but is a part of the reconstructive process after excision.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The most appropriate management strategy for squamous cell carcinoma of the neck with negative lymph nodes is wide local excision to remove the tumor completely, often followed by radiotherapy to address any potential microscopic residual disease.

questions.text: In Modified Radical Neck Dissection (MRND), which of the following structures is not preserved? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Submandibular gland 

 

In a Modified Radical Neck Dissection (MRND), the goal is to remove lymphatic tissue that may contain cancer while preserving as many structures as possible to reduce morbidity. 

 

Option A. Sternocleidomastoid muscle: In an MRND, this muscle is typically preserved unless it is involved with the tumor.

 

Option B. Internal jugular vein: This vein is usually preserved in an MRND to maintain venous drainage from the head, unless it is involved with the tumor.

 

Option C. Spinal accessory nerve: Preservation of the spinal accessory nerve is a key goal in MRND to prevent shoulder dysfunction that can occur if the nerve is sacrificed.

 

Option D. Submandibular gland: The submandibular gland is routinely removed in an MRND, especially if the lymph nodes closely associated with it are involved with malignant disease.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

In Modified Radical Neck Dissection, the sternocleidomastoid muscle, internal jugular vein, and spinal accessory nerve are typically preserved to reduce morbidity, while the submandibular gland is often removed due to its close association with lymphatic structures that are at risk for malignancy.

choices.text: IV antibiotics, IV fluids, culture, assisted drainage, and MRI
IV fluids, MRI, assisted drainage, and laparotomy
IV antibiotics, IV fluids, culture, and assisted drainage
IV antibiotics, IV fluids, culture, assisted drainage, MRI, and laparotomy

questions.text: Which of the following steps are included in the management of acute necrotizing pancreatitis in a patient with large intra-abdominal fluid accumulation and pancreatic necrosis?  (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) IV antibiotics, IV fluids, culture, and assisted drainage

 

MRI is not indicated in patients with acute necrotising pancreatitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct steps in the management of acute necrotizing pancreatitis include IV antibiotics, IV fluids, culture, and assisted drainage. Large intra-abdominal fluid accumulation and pancreatic necrosis are complications of acute pancreatitis that require immediate management.

 

Aggressive fluid resuscitation, pain control, and early nutrition are initiated, followed by contrast-enhanced computed tomography to diagnose necrosis. If infected necrosis is suspected, fine-needle aspiration is done, and the aspirate is subjected to Gram staining and culture sensitivity. IV antibiotics are started with carbapenem as the first-choice drug.

 

The step-up approach, which includes percutaneous drainage followed by minimally invasive video-assisted retroperitoneal debridement, is adopted for definitive management. Hence, the correct option is C) IV antibiotics, IV fluids, culture, and assisted drainage.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male pt presented to your clinic with persistent non-pitting edema in their lower extremities as shown below. What could be the most likely reason for this symptom? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lymphedema

 

  • Lymphedema is the likeliest cause.
  • It involves the build-up of protein-rich fluid in tissue interstitial spaces.
  • It shows typical “non-pitting” edema in the second stage of lymphedema.
  • Filariasis is the most common etiology.
  • In severe and long standing cases, skin changes are seen giving the limb an appearance of “Elephantiasis”.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Arterial Disorders: Arterial disorders may lead to symptoms such as leg pain, intermittent claudication, and tissue damage due to reduced blood supply. Edema is uncommon.

 

Option C. Venous Disorders: These disorders can encompass conditions like deep vein thrombosis (DVT), varicose veins, chronic venous insufficiency (CVI), and venous ulcers. Venous disorders may result in symptoms like leg swelling, pain, and skin changes, and they can vary in severity. No evidence of skin changes associated with varicose veins are seen.

 

Option D. Coronary Heart Disease: Coronary heart disease (CHD), also known as coronary artery disease (CAD), is a common heart condition where the coronary arteries that supply blood to the heart muscle become narrowed or blocked due to the buildup of fatty deposits (atherosclerosis). CAD may lead to heart failure leading to bilateral lower limb pitting edema, which is not seen in the case above.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lymphedema is characterized by non-pitting edema due to the accumulation of protein-rich fluid in the tissue interstitial spaces. It can lead to significant swelling and skin changes, particularly in the lower extremities, distinguishing it from other causes of edema.

questions.text: A teenage patient came with pain and a palpable lump in Right iliac fossa. Blood investigation shows increased TLC. What is the management? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Oschner Sherren regime

 

The patient, a teenager, presents with pain and a palpable lump in the right iliac fossa (RIF), along with an increased total leukocyte count (TLC). These findings are suggestive of acute appendicitis with an appendicular phlegmon. An appendicular phlegmon occurs when inflammation spreads, and the omentum and other structures seal off the inflamed appendix, forming a palpable mass.

 

In this scenario, immediate surgical intervention such as laparoscopy or open appendectomy is not recommended because it involves breaking the seal formed by the omentum, complicating the procedure. Instead, the preferred management is conservative, following the Oschner Sherren regime. This regimen involves:

 

  • Keeping the patient nil by mouth (NPO).
  • Administering intravenous antibiotics to control infection.
  • Providing intravenous fluids for hydration.
  • Observing the patient until the inflammation subsides.

 

Once the lump resolves and the infection is under control, an interval appendectomy can be performed later.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Laparoscopy Appendectomy: This is not recommended in the presence of an appendicular phlegmon.

 

Option C. Alvarado regime: This is a scoring system used to assess the likelihood of appendicitis, not a management strategy.

 

Option D. Open Appendectomy: This is not recommended when a phlegmon is present.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Oschner Sherren regime is the conservative management approach for an appendicular phlegmon, involving NPO status, IV antibiotics, and fluids, followed by interval appendectomy.

questions.text: Image of a patient with large ulcerated breast cancer with liver metastasis. What is the management? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Simple mastectomy

 

The patient in the image has a large ulcerated breast tumor with confirmed liver metastasis, classifying the cancer as stage IV (T4, M1). In cases of stage IV breast cancer with distant metastasis, the primary goal of management shifts from curative to palliative care, focusing on improving quality of life and managing symptoms.

For patients with large ulcerated tumors, palliative simple mastectomy may be considered to alleviate symptoms like pain, ulceration, discharge, or infection, which can significantly impact the patient’s quality of life. This procedure is not intended to cure but to provide local control of the tumor and improve comfort.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. MRM (Modified Radical Mastectomy): This is a more aggressive surgical approach that involves removal of the breast tissue along with axillary lymph nodes. It is typically reserved for curative intent in earlier stages of breast cancer without distant metastasis. It is not appropriate for palliation in stage IV disease with liver metastasis.

 

Option C. Radical mastectomy: This involves removal of the entire breast, underlying chest muscles, and axillary lymph nodes. This extensive procedure is rarely performed today and is not suitable for palliative care in metastatic disease due to its high morbidity without a survival benefit.

 

Option D. Neoadjuvant chemotherapy followed by surgery: Neoadjuvant chemotherapy is used in locally advanced breast cancer (LABC) to shrink tumors before surgery, but in the presence of distant metastasis (M1), systemic chemotherapy alone would be preferred for palliative purposes. Surgery would only follow if there was a significant symptomatic tumor burden requiring local control.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with stage IV breast cancer with distant metastasis, such as liver metastasis, the primary focus is on palliation. Simple mastectomy may be performed to manage symptoms from a large ulcerated tumor, but more extensive surgeries or curative approaches are not indicated.

questions.text: All of the following are clinical features of thromboangitis obliterans except:(NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Absence of popliteal pulse

 

Explanation:

 

Thromboangitis obliterans (Buerger's disease) classically presents with a triad of symptoms including intermittent claudication, superficial thrombophlebitis, and Raynaud's phenomenon. Buerger's disease typically affects small and medium-sized arteries distal to the popliteal artery rather than the popliteal artery itself. The disease primarily affects young male smokers under 40 years of age. The popliteal pulse is usually preserved in Buerger's disease, as the pathology affects more distal vessels.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Raynaud's phenomenon - This is part of the classic triad of Buerger's disease, characterized by cyclical color changes in digits upon exposure to cold, stress, or vibratory tools due to vasospasm.

 

Option B. Claudication of extremities - Intermittent claudication is a core feature of Buerger's disease and part of the classic triad.

 

Option D. Migratory superficial thrombophlebitis - This is another component of the classic triad of Buerger's disease.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Buerger's disease (thromboangitis obliterans) typically affects small to medium-sized arteries distal to the popliteal artery, presenting with the classic triad of intermittent claudication, superficial thrombophlebitis, and Raynaud's phenomenon, while preserving more proximal pulses such as the popliteal pulse.

questions.text: Which of the below is the most preferred investigation for parathyroid adenoma localisation? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sestamibi SPECT

 

This is the preferred diagnostic tool for identifying parathyroid adenomas. The technique involves the use of a radioactive tracer, typically Technetium-99m sestamibi, which is absorbed by hyperactive parathyroid tissue more than normal tissue. SPECT provides three-dimensional imaging, improving the localization of hyperactive parathyroid glands.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CT (Computed Tomography): CT scans are not typically the first line of imaging due to the high levels of radiation exposure and the potential need for contrast agents.

 

Option C. Technetium-99m Sestamibi (tech99-Sestamibi) scan: This is a nuclear imaging which uses a gamma camera for imaging.

 

Option D. USG (Ultrasound): Ultrasound is a non-invasive, widely available, and less expensive method to examine the neck for parathyroid adenomas. It is particularly useful in conjunction with Sestamibi scans, as it helps to evaluate the structure of the neck and localize adenomas. However, its effectiveness can be limited by the operator's experience and the patient's anatomy.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

While all these methods can assist in the diagnosis and localization of parathyroid adenomas, Sestamibi SPECT is generally considered the most effective standalone imaging modality due to its high specificity for active parathyroid tissue and its ability to provide detailed spatial resolution. It is particularly valuable in surgical planning to ensure precise removal of the adenoma.

choices.text: Rest pain is seen more in the night
Pain in intermittent claudication comes at first step of walking.
The clinical stem does not reflect the site of peripheral arterial obstruction

questions.text: Which of the statements regarding claudication pain is incorrect? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pain in intermittent claudication comes at first step of walking.

 

Intermittent claudication is characterized by muscle pain (ache, cramp, numbness or sense of fatigue), classically in the calf muscle, which occurs during exercise and is relieved by a short period of rest (< 5 minutes). The pain does not typically start with the first step but develops after a predictable distance of walking.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rest pain is seen more in the night: True. Rest pain is a more severe symptom of peripheral artery disease (PAD). It typically indicates more advanced disease than intermittent claudication. This pain occurs when the limb is at rest, often at night due to the decreased perfusion that results from the horizontal position of the limb. It often awakens the patient from sleep and can be relieved by hanging the leg over the bed or walking.

 

Option C. Most common cause is atheroma: True. The most common cause of intermittent claudication is atherosclerosis (plaque or atheroma formation) in the peripheral arteries. This reduces blood flow to the muscles during activity, causing pain.

 

Option D. The clinical stem does not reflect the site of peripheral arterial obstruction: True. The site of pain (e.g., calf, thigh) does not always directly correlate with the level of arterial obstruction. For instance, while calf pain is often due to femoropopliteal disease, it can also be caused by aortoiliac disease. However, the location of claudication pain can provide a clue to the level of disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The incorrect statement among the provided options is that pain in intermittent claudication occurs at the first step of walking.

questions.text: Pressure on the artery proximal to an A-V fistula causes all of the following, except: (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Increase in heart rate

 

Explanation:

 

In arteriovenous (A-V) fistulas, pressure on the artery proximal to the fistula reduces blood flow through the fistula. This causes a reduction in the size of the dilated veins, eliminates the thrill (palpable vibration), and stops the continuous bruit ("machinery murmur"). This occurs because proximal arterial compression blocks the arterial inflow to the fistula. However, heart rate is reduced, known as Branham’s bradycardia. This occurs as the hyperdynamic circulation due to the fistula reverts to normal.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Reduced size - When pressure is applied to the artery proximal to the fistula, the swelling of the arteriovenous fistula decreases as blood flow is reduced through the abnormal connection.

 

Option C. Reduced thrill - The thrill (palpable vibration) over an A-V fistula disappears when pressure is applied to the proximal artery because it interrupts the turbulent blood flow that creates the thrill.

 

Option D. Reduced pulse pressure - Compression of the feeding artery reduces blood flow through the fistula, eliminating the hemodynamic effects including the high-pulse pressure characteristic of A-V fistulas.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Proximal arterial compression in A-V fistulas reduces local hemodynamic effects (size, thrill, bruit) by interrupting blood flow, while the heart rate reduces.

questions.text: What is the most common complication of ERCP? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pancreatitis

 

Many complications can occur with Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography (ERCP), a procedure used to diagnose and treat conditions of the bile ducts and pancreatic duct. 

 

This is the inflammation of the pancreas and is the most common complication of ERCP seen in 1-3% patients. It can occur due to irritation or injury to the pancreas during the procedure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Duodenal perforation: This is a serious but less common complication of ERCP. It can occur when the endoscope or the instruments used during the procedure inadvertently create a hole in the intestinal wall.

 

Option B. Cholangitis: This is an infection of the bile duct system. It can occur if bacteria spread during the procedure, especially if there is an obstruction within the bile ducts that has not been adequately drained.

 

Option C. Hemorrhage: Bleeding can occur, particularly if a sphincterotomy (cutting of the sphincter of Oddi to access the bile duct) is performed. While bleeding is a risk, it is not the most common complication.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Post-ERCP pancreatitis is the most common complication following ERCP, necessitating careful risk assessment and patient monitoring post-procedure.

questions.text: A 51-year-old woman who had an abdominal hysterectomy two years ago and is now experiencing abdominal pain, vomiting bile, high-pitched bowel sounds during examination. The presence of air within the biliary tree is seen on diagnostic tests. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Gallstone ileus

 

The given clinical scenario is suggestive of intestinal obstruction. Though adhesions could be the reason, the presence of air in biliary tree makes a diagnosis of gallstone ileus more likely.

 

  • Gallstone ileus is a rare complication of cholelithiasis, occurring due to the impaction of gallstones in the gastrointestinal tract. This occurs due to chronic gall bladder inflammation and formation of cholecysto-duodenal fistula (GB to duodenum). Through the communication, a gall stone may pass into the duodenum and then into small bowel.
  • Small gallstones may pass through the intestines spontaneously, but larger stones (2-5 cm) are more likely to cause obstruction, usually at the terminal ileum or ileocecal valve.
  • Symptoms may include acute, intermittent, or chronic episodes of gastrointestinal obstruction, abdominal distension and tenderness, high-pitched bowel sounds, and obstructive jaundice.
  • Diagnosis is typically made with a plain abdominal radiograph, which may show signs of obstruction, Pneumobilia (air within the biliary tree), and a gallstone in the intestines (RIGLER’S TRIAD).
  • Treatment involves surgical intervention, with a longitudinal incision made on the antimesenteric border to remove the gallstone.

 

 Other Options:

 

Option B. Adhesive intestinal obstruction: This results from the formation of adhesions (bands of scar tissue) that can develop after surgery, which then bind the intestines together. These adhesions can pull the intestines out of place or create a kink or twist. The patient's history of an abdominal hysterectomy is suggestive of this, as post-surgical adhesions are a common cause of intestinal obstruction. However, the presence of air in the biliary tree does not fit with this diagnosis.

 

Option C. Ischemic enterocolitis: Refers to inflammation of the intestine due to reduced blood supply, often caused by blockage or constriction of the blood vessels that serve the intestines. Symptoms typically include sudden abdominal pain and bloody diarrhea. While ischemic processes can cause pain and altered bowel sounds, the presence of pneumobilia on imaging is not consistent with ischemic enterocolitis.

 

Option D. Diverticulitis: Diverticulitis is the inflammation of one or more diverticula, which are small pouches that can form in the walls of the colon. Symptoms include lower left-sided abdominal pain, fever, and changes in bowel habits. While diverticulitis can lead to complications like abscesses, fistulas, or bowel obstructions, the specific presentation of vomiting bile and air within the biliary tree on imaging is not consistent with a primary diagnosis of diverticulitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Gallstone ileus is a rare complication of cholelithiasis characterized by the presence of air within the biliary tree, obstructive symptoms, and the formation of a cholecysto-duodenal fistula.
  • It typically presents with signs of gastrointestinal obstruction and is diagnosed through imaging, revealing pneumobilia and a gallstone in the intestines.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents to the surgeon with a recurrent inguinal hernia. The surgeon decides to perform a hernioplasty, and the patient inquiries about the most appropriate type of mesh to be used. The surgeon wants to ensure that the patient is aware of the various types of meshes that can be used in hernioplasty. Which of the following is the most appropriate mesh for use in hernioplasty? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Lightweight mesh with large pores

 

Lightweight meshes with large pores are considered the most appropriate choice for hernioplasty. They provide adequate support to repair the hernia while allowing for better tissue integration and reduced inflammation. This type of mesh is associated with lower postoperative pain and discomfort.

 

Heavyweight mesh:

 

  • Heavyweight meshes are typically not recommended for hernioplasty because they can lead to increased inflammation, tissue response, and a higher risk of complications. They may cause stiffness and discomfort in the area.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The most appropriate mesh to use in hernioplasty is a lightweight mesh with large pores.
  • Lightweight meshes induce a less-pronounced foreign body reaction and decreased inflammatory response, leading to better tissue incorporation, increased prosthesis compliance, and decreased patient discomfort and pain.
  • Meshes with large pores allow for increased soft tissue ingrowth and exhibit less inflammatory infiltrate, connective tissue, and scar bridging. This results in less adhesion, better tissue incorporation, and decreased patient discomfort and pain.
  • “Meshes with thinner strands and larger spaces (pores) between them are preferred because they have better tissue integration, less contracture, less foreign body reaction, more flexibility and improved comfort.” Bailey 28th Ed. Pg 1063.
  • Meshes used in hernioplasty can be synthetic or biological, with synthetic meshes made from Polypropylene, Polyester, or PTFE.

questions.text: Identify the parameter seen in all types of shock: (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Decreased Tissue Perfusion

 

Decreased tissue perfusion is a constant feature in all types of shock. Shock is defined as a systemic state of low tissue perfusion that is inadequate for normal cellular respiration. Regardless of the type, the hallmark of shock is reduced blood flow to the tissues, resulting in insufficient oxygen delivery and nutrient supply to meet the cellular needs, leading to cellular and tissue hypoxia.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increased Temperature: Increased temperature or fever is not seen in all types of shock. It is commonly seen in septic shock due to the systemic inflammatory response to infection.

 

Option B. Increased Pulse Pressure: Increased pulse pressure is not a consistent finding in all types of shock. In fact, pulse pressure often narrows in states like hypovolemic and cardiogenic shock.

 

Option C. Increased Peripheral Resistance: Increased peripheral resistance (SVR) is not present in all types of shock. For example, septic and anaphylactic shock are characterized by decreased SVR due to widespread vasodilation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Decreased tissue perfusion is a universal characteristic of all types of shock, leading to inadequate oxygen and nutrient delivery to tissues.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man came with complaints of dark-colored stools to the OPD. After undergoing endoscopy, the patient was diagnosed with an upper GI bleed. Which of the following structures is used as a demarcation point to differentiate it from a lower GI bleed?(NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Ligament of Treitz

 

The ligament of Treitz is used as the demarcation point to differentiate between upper gastrointestinal bleeding and lower gastrointestinal bleeding. It is a part of the duodenojejunal junction.

 

Upper GI bleeding refers to bleeding proximal to the ligament of Treitz, and lower Gl bleeding refers to bleeding distal to the ligament of Treitz.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ampulla of Vater: The ampulla of Vater is the point where the pancreatic duct and common bile duct converge and enter the second part of the duodenum. It is an essential structure for the drainage of both bile and pancreatic enzymes into the duodenum. It is not used as a demarcation point for differentiating between upper and lower gastrointestinal bleeding.

 

Option C. Superior duodenal flexure: The superior duodenal flexure is the bend in the duodenum as it transitions from the first part (horizontal) to the second part (descending).

 

Option D. Ileocecal junction: The ileocecal junction is the point where the ileum meets the cecum. The ileocecal valve is present here, preventing the reflux of colonic contents into the ileum. While it's an important anatomical landmark in the gastrointestinal tract, it's not used as the demarcation point for differentiating between upper and lower gastrointestinal bleeding.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The ligament of Treitz is the anatomical demarcation point used to differentiate upper gastrointestinal bleeding (proximal to the ligament) from lower gastrointestinal bleeding (distal to the ligament).

questions.text: A 40-year-old female victim of RTA presents to the ER. On examination, GCS is 15/15, heart rate = 110/min, BP = 90/60 mmHg, and there is elevated JVP. The right chest is tympanic on percussion with decreased breath sounds on auscultation. The left chest appears normal. But the patient is dyspneic and ecchymosis is noted over the chest wall. The abdomen is soft. The probable diagnosis is: (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tension Pneumothorax

 

The given clinical scenario of hemodynamic instability, tympanic note (hyper-resonant) on percussion, and decreased breath sounds on the affected side is suggestive of tension pneumothorax.

 

Tension pneumothorax occurs when air accumulates in the pleural space and cannot escape, leading to increased pressure in the chest cavity. This condition can compress the lungs and the great vessels in the chest, causing respiratory distress, hypotension, elevated JVP, and decreased breath sounds on auscultation. Tympanic percussion note over the right chest is consistent with air in the pleural space. Ecchymosis (bruising) over the chest wall can result from trauma and rib fractures associated with tension pneumothorax.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cardiac tamponade: Cardiac tamponade typically presents with symptoms such as hypotension, muffled heart sounds, and distended neck veins (Jugular Venous Pressure - JVP). While elevated JVP is mentioned in the scenario, the other symptoms associated with cardiac tamponade, such as muffled heart sounds and hypotension, are not present.

 

Option C. Pericardial effusion: Pericardial effusion involves the accumulation of fluid around the heart. While it can cause elevated JVP, it typically presents with other cardiac symptoms, such as muffled heart sounds and chest pain. The scenario does not mention these cardiac-specific symptoms.

 

Option D. Massive hemothorax: Massive hemothorax refers to a significant accumulation of blood in the pleural space. It can cause decreased breath sounds, but it is not typically associated with a tympanic percussion note or elevated JVP unless there is concurrent tension pneumothorax.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A tension pneumothorax develops when there is a tear is either in the parietal or visceral pleura. This tear acts as a one-way valve i.e., air enters from the lung or chest wall through it during inspiration but has no way to escape during expiration. This ultimately causes collapse of the affected lung.

 

It is characterized by:

 

  • Chest pain
  • Tachypnoea, and acute dyspnea
  • Sudden onset hemodynamic compromise (tachycardia, hypotension, low O2 saturation, loss of consciousness)
  • Neck vein distention
  • Tracheal deviation away from the side of injury
  • Decreased chest movements on the affected side
  • Hyper-resonance on percussion on the affected side
  • Absence or decreased breath sounds on the affected side

 

Tension pneumothorax is a clinical diagnosis, and treatment must never be delayed waiting for radiological confirmation. Management includes:

 

  • Immediate management: Needle decompression or needle thoracostomy i.e. insertion of a wide-bore needle in the 5th ICS anterior to the midaxillary line. In the pediatric age group, the needle thoracostomy location is at the 2nd ICS midclavicular line.
  • Definitive management: Tube thoracostomy or chest tube insertion in the 5th ICS in the triangle of safety.

questions.text: Identify the instrument in the image below? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bipolar cautery

 

The given instrument is a Bipolar cautery

 

  • Bipolar cautery, like unipolar cautery, is a form of electrosurgery used for tissue coagulation and hemostasis.
  • Unlike unipolar cautery, bipolar cautery uses two electrodes that are very close together on the surgical instrument. The electrical current flows only between these two closely spaced electrodes, which limits the current's path to a small area of tissue.
  • Bipolar cautery is often preferred in delicate surgical procedures where precise tissue coagulation is required, as it has a more localized effect compared to unipolar cautery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Unipolar cautery: 

 

  • Unipolar cautery is a type of electrosurgery that uses a single electrode for cutting or coagulating tissue. It is commonly used for various surgical procedures to cut or coagulate tissues, control bleeding, and achieve hemostasis.

 

 

Option C. The harmonic scalpel:

 

  • The harmonic scalpel is known for its precision and minimal thermal spread, making it suitable for various surgical procedures, including laparoscopic and open surgeries.
  • It allows surgeons to dissect tissues and achieve hemostasis with minimal damage to surrounding structures, based on generation of heat from ultrasonic waves.

 

 

Option D. LigaSure vessel sealing system:

 

  • LigaSure is known for its ability to create secure and consistent vessel seals, reducing the risk of bleeding during surgery.
  • It is a type of advanced bipolar vessel sealing device.
  • It is commonly used in a wide range of surgical specialties, including general surgery, gynecology, and urology, among others.

 

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Bipolar cautery is ideal for controlled, precise tissue coagulation in delicate surgeries due to its localized current flow, making it more specific than unipolar cautery.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents to the clinic with symptoms of acute bacterial prostatitis, including fever, chills, dysuria, and perineal pain. A urine sample is taken, and a culture is performed, which reveals the presence of a common organism associated with acute bacterial prostatitis. Identify the organism?(NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. E. coli

 

Escherichia coli, commonly known as E. coli, is a gram-negative bacillus and is part of the normal flora of the gastrointestinal tract. E. coli is the most common cause of acute bacterial prostatitis, accounting for the vast majority of cases. It's also a very common cause of urinary tract infections in general.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Enterococcus: Enterococcus species are gram-positive cocci that are part of the normal gut flora. They are an infrequent cause of acute bacterial prostatitis.

 

Option B. Proteus: Proteus species are gram-negative bacilli. They can cause a variety of infections, including urinary tract infections and, less commonly, prostatitis. A characteristic of Proteus infections is the production of urease, which splits urea into ammonia and leads to an alkaline urine that can cause struvite stone formation.

 

Option C. Streptococcus Agalactiae: Also known as Group B Streptococcus (GBS), Streptococcus agalactiae is a gram-positive coccus. While it's a leading cause of neonatal infections, it's an infrequent cause of urinary tract infections in adults and an even rarer cause of prostatitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Escherichia coli (E. coli) is the most common cause of acute bacterial prostatitis, accounting for the majority of cases and is frequently found in urinary tract infections.

questions.text: A female presented with pain and redness of the left breast. She is lactating for the last 3 months. On examination, local temperature is raised and cracked nipple is noted. Ultrasound of breast was suggestive of significant liquid collection. What should be the next line of management? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Incision and drainage

 

The clinical presentation of a postpartum female with fever, pain, and swelling of the breast, along with an ultrasound showing fluid collection, is indicative of a breast abscess.

 

Breast abscesses are more common in lactating women due to faulty breastfeeding techniques, with cracked nipples being a significant risk factor. The most common causative organism is Staphylococcus aureus, often sourced from the oropharynx of the child.

 

This is the definitive treatment for a breast abscess, especially when there is a significant collection of fluid, as indicated by the ultrasound.

 

Diagnosis:


Diagnosis is based on clinical examination and confirmed by ultrasound, which shows fluid collection indicative of an abscess.

 

Treatment:

 

  • Primary Treatment: Incision and drainage (I&D) is the mainstay of treatment for a confirmed breast abscess.
  • Antibiotics: While antibiotics (such as Amoxiclav) are important, they are adjunctive to the drainage procedure.
  • Needle Aspirations: Ultrasound-guided needle aspiration can be attempted, especially if the abscess is small. However, if multiple attempts fail, incision and drainage become necessary.
  • Suction Catheter Drainage: For large abscesses (>3 cm or >30 cc), suction catheter drainage is an effective management strategy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Antibiotics: Antibiotics alone are not sufficient to treat a breast abscess as they do not address the pus collection. They are used in conjunction with drainage procedures.

 

Option B. Multiple needle aspirations: Ultrasound-guided needle aspiration can be attempted, but if it fails after at least two attempts, incision and drainage are indicated.

 

Option D. Breast support: While providing breast support is important for comfort and to help reduce pain, it is not a primary treatment method for a breast abscess.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The primary treatment for a breast abscess in a lactating woman is incision and drainage, along with the use of antibiotics to manage infection.

questions.text:
A 73-year-old individual arrives with painless rectal bleeding. Which of the listed investigations are conducted for this patient? (INICET MAY 2023)

 

  1. Colonoscopy
  2. CECT
  3. CEA
  4. CA 19-9
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 2 and 3

 

1. Colonoscopy: This is an endoscopic examination of the large bowel and the distal part of the small bowel. It provides a visual diagnosis and can offer biopsy or removal of suspected lesions. It is an essential diagnostic tool for any patient with per-rectal bleeding to identify potential sources such as polyps, tumors, or colitis.

 

2. CECT (Contrast-Enhanced Computed Tomography):  CECT can provide detailed cross-sectional images of the body. In the context of rectal bleeding, it might be used to evaluate the extent of a detected tumor, check for metastatic disease, or to view vascular anomalies that might be causing the bleeding, such as arteriovenous malformations.

 

3. CEA (Carcinoembryonic Antigen): CEA is a tumor marker. Its level can be elevated in colorectal cancers as well as other malignancies and conditions. Monitoring the levels of CEA might help in diagnosing, prognosis, and checking the recurrence of colorectal cancers. 

 

Other Option:

 

4. CA 19-9: CA 19-9 is another tumor marker. It is more typically associated with pancreatic cancer. However, its specificity for colorectal cancer is not as high as CEA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Given the patient's presenting symptom of painless rectal bleeding:

 

  • Colonoscopy is a primary diagnostic tool to visualize and biopsy any potential sources of bleeding.
  • CECT could be useful in determining the extent of a potential tumor or to check for other causes of bleeding.
  • CEA might be used to check for the possibility of colorectal cancer.

 

Hence, the investigations that would be most appropriate and relevant for this patient would be options 1, 2, and 3. Therefore, answer choice D) 1, 2, and 3 is correct.

questions.text: A woman in her early 40s comes to your clinic, displaying a winding, pronounced swelling that covers the left region of her scalp and face, as visible in the provided image. Upon physical examination, you notice the swelling exhibits a rhythmic pulsation. When listening to the area with a stethoscope, a sound indicative of turbulent blood flow - a bruit - is heard. What could be the most probable diagnosis in this case? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cirsoid Aneurysm

 

The above image is suggestive of a Cirsoid aneurysm.

 

  1. Definition: Cirsoid aneurysms, also known as arteriovenous fistulas or arteriovenous malformations, are abnormal connections between arteries and veins without the usual intervening capillaries.
  2. Common locations: They most commonly occur in the scalp and face, although they can occur in other locations in the body.
  3. Causes: They can be congenital (present at birth) or acquired, often as a result of trauma.
  4. Symptoms: Cirsoid aneurysms often present as a pulsatile mass, sometimes accompanied by a bruit (a sound heard over an artery due to turbulent blood flow). They can cause cosmetic concerns, headaches, and in severe cases, bleeding.
  5. Diagnosis: They can be diagnosed through physical examination and imaging studies such as ultrasound, CT, or MRI. Angiography can provide a detailed view of the blood vessels.
  6. Treatment: Treatment options include surgical excision, embolization (blocking off the abnormal vessels), or a combination of both. The choice of treatment depends on the size and location of the aneurysm, and the patient's overall health status.
  7. Complications: If left untreated, they can result in complications such as bleeding, ulceration, and, rarely, heart failure due to the increased blood flow through the malformation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Neurofibromatosis:

 

  • Location: Neurofibromatosis (NF) is a genetic disorder that can affect multiple systems, including the skin and nerves.
  • Symptoms: Symptoms vary but can include skin tumors (neurofibromas), café-au-lait spots, and neurological problems

 

 

Option B. Liposarcoma:

 

  • Location: Liposarcoma is a type of soft tissue sarcoma that typically arises in fat cells in various parts of the body, including the limbs and abdomen.
  • Causes: The exact cause is often unknown, but some genetic factors may contribute. Symptoms: Symptoms may include a painless lump, swelling, or pain in the affected area.

 

Option D. Varicocele:

 

  • Location: Varicoceles are dilated veins in the scrotum, specifically in the spermatic cord. Causes: Varicoceles often develop due to faulty valves in the testicular veins, which allow blood to pool in the scrotum.
  • Symptoms: They may cause a dull ache or discomfort in the scrotum, especially after prolonged standing.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cirsoid aneurysms are arteriovenous malformations commonly found in the scalp and face, presenting as pulsatile masses with associated bruits. Proper diagnosis and treatment are essential to prevent complications such as bleeding and cosmetic concerns.

questions.text: A 27-year-old accountant underwent parotidectomy following which she developed lower lip paralysis. This probably occurred because of an injury to which of the following structures? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Mandibular branch of facial nerve

 

The mandibular branch of the facial nerve, also known as the marginal mandibular branch, supplies motor fibers to the muscles responsible for lower lip movement. During a parotidectomy, there is a risk of injuring the nearby facial nerve branches, including the mandibular branch. Damage to this branch can lead to lower lip paralysis or weakness.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Temporal branch of facial nerve: The temporal branch of the facial nerve innervates the muscles of the forehead and is not related to the lower lip.

 

Option B. Cervical branch of facial nerve: The cervical branch of the facial nerve innervates certain neck muscles and is also not related to the lower lip.

 

Option C. Parotid duct: The parotid duct, also known as Stensen's duct, carries saliva from the parotid gland to the mouth. Injury to this duct could result in salivary leakage from wound (salivary fistula).

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Lower lip paralysis is a result of an injury to the marginal mandibular branch of the facial nerve.
  • During parotidectomy, the facial nerve may be at risk of injury since it passes through the parotid gland.
  • The branches of the facial nerve include the temporal, zygomatic, buccal, marginal mandibular, and cervical branches.

questions.text:
What investigations would you recommend for a female patient who presents with a 4cm x 3cm irregular mass in the upper outer quadrant of the right breast and a palpated lymph node of 2cm in the right axilla, but no mass palpated in the opposite breast? (AIIMS NOV 2020)

 

  1. Bilateral Mammography
  2. PET Scan
  3. Biopsy of the breast mass
  4. USG guided biopsy of the lymph node
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 3, 4

 

  • The clinical presentation indicates that the patient may have breast cancer with local spread but no distant metastasis. To further investigate this, it is recommended to conduct bilateral mammography, biopsy of the breast mass (Triple assessment), and USG-guided biopsy of the suspicious lymph node.
  • Diagnostic mammography is a useful tool for examining women with abnormal findings, including breast masses and nipple discharge, and it is more accurate than clinical examination in detecting early breast cancers.
  • Breast cancer can be identified through mammographic features such as a solid mass with or without stellate features, asymmetric thickening of breast tissue, or clustered microcalcifications.
  • To diagnose carcinoma, a core needle biopsy or fine-needle aspiration is usually performed before any treatment begins. In cases where suspicious lymph nodes are present, US-guided fine-needle aspiration or core biopsy is performed to determine the presence of metastatic disease.
  • PET scans are typically done after completion of triple assessment and confirmation of malignancy of breast.

choices.text: Resection of the diseased segment and end-to-end anastomosis
Cleaning the edges of the ulcer and apply the Omental patch

questions.text: A patient was brought to the emergency with diffuse abdominal pain and abdominal wall rigidity. Exploratory laparotomy was done and the following was found. What would you do in the management of this patient? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Simple primary repair

 

The scenario described suggests that the patient has a perforation of the small bowel, as indicated by the image showing a hole in the intestine. Abdominal wall rigidity is indicative of peritonitis, which results from the leakage of intestinal contents into the peritoneal cavity due to a perforation. The provided images and description align with a small bowel perforation, likely in the jejunum or ileum.

 

In cases of small bowel perforations, particularly when the perforation is small, the standard management is a simple primary repair. This involves suturing the perforation directly, which is often sufficient to manage the defect without the need for more extensive surgery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Resection of the diseased segment and end-to-end anastomosis:
This is typically reserved for cases where the perforation is large, there are multiple perforations, or when the perforation is associated with a pathological condition like a stricture like in tubercular perforation. In the case described, a simple primary repair is usually sufficient.

 

Option B. Cleaning the edges of the ulcer and apply the Omental patch: This procedure, known as an omental patch or Graham's patch, is more commonly used for duodenal ulcers, not for small bowel perforations.

 

Option D. Purse string suture: This technique is not commonly used for repairing small bowel perforations. It is more suitable for specific types of perforations or fistulas but not typically indicated in the described scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For small bowel perforations, particularly in the jejunum or ileum, the primary approach is often a simple primary repair. This involves directly suturing the perforation and is usually effective for managing small perforations.

questions.text: Which of the following gastrointestinal polyposis syndromes is associated with congenital hypertrophy of retinal pigment epithelium (CHRPE)?(NEET PG 2014)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Gardner's Syndrome

 

Explanation:

 

Congenital Hypertrophy of Retinal Pigment Epithelium (CHRPE) is observed in over 90% of patients with Gardner’s Syndrome and is frequently bilateral. Gardner’s Syndrome is a variant of Familial Adenomatous Polyposis (FAP) with additional extracolonic manifestations.

 

Features of Gardner's Syndrome

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cowden’s Syndrome: Characterized by multiple hamartomas and an increased risk of breast, thyroid, and endometrial cancers. CHRPE is not a feature of this syndrome.

 

Option C. Muir-Torre Syndrome: Associated with sebaceous gland tumors and visceral malignancies, primarily colorectal cancer. CHRPE is not associated with this syndrome.

 

Option D. Turcot’s Syndrome: Involves the association of colorectal polyposis with brain tumors. CHRPE is not a characteristic feature of this syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gardner's Syndrome is associated with congenital hypertrophy of retinal pigment epithelium (CHRPE), seen in more than 90% of patients, often bilaterally.

questions.text: An alcoholic patient presented with features of chronic pancreatitis with recurrent attacks and has a 10 mm dilatation of the pancreatic duct with intraductal calculi present. Which of the following is the surgery of choice? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Longitudinal pancreaticojejunostomy

 

  • In the given scenario of dilated pancreatic duct with stones, a drainage procedure in the form of longitudinal pancreatico-jejunostomy (Peusthow) is preferred.
  • CHRONIC PANCREATITIS - Irreversible damage to architecture of pancreas.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pancreaticoduodenectomy (Whipple’s procedure): This procedure involves the removal of the head of the pancreas, duodenum, gallbladder, and bile duct. It is typically reserved for malignancies or specific inflammatory conditions localized to the head of the pancreas. It is not the primary choice for diffuse chronic pancreatitis with a dilated duct.

 

Option C. ERCP and sphincterotomy: ERCP (Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography) with sphincterotomy can aid in the removal of pancreatic calculi but is not considered a long-term solution for chronic pancreatitis with a significantly dilated duct.

 

Option D. Coring of the pancreas head: Coring of the pancreatic head may be considered if inflammation is limited to the head of the pancreas alone, but it is not suitable for the diffuse dilation of the pancreatic duct with intraductal calculi.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In patients with chronic pancreatitis and a significantly dilated pancreatic duct (greater than 6 mm), the preferred surgical treatment is longitudinal pancreaticojejunostomy (Peustow procedure).
  • This procedure helps to relieve ductal hypertension and improve drainage, alleviating pain and other symptoms associated with chronic pancreatitis.

choices.text: Stricture of the bulb of the urethra

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common cause of delayed urinary tract obstructive symptoms after TURP: (NEET PG 2014)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Bladder neck stenosis

 

Explanation:

 

Bladder neck stenosis, also known as bladder neck contracture, is the most common cause of delayed urinary tract obstructive symptoms following Transurethral Resection of the Prostate (TURP). This condition occurs due to scarring and narrowing at the bladder neck, which can obstruct the flow of urine. It is a recognized late complication of TURP.

 

Late Complications of TURP

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stricture of the navicular fossa: This is a rare complication and not the most common cause of delayed obstructive symptoms post-TURP.

 

Option B. Stricture of the membranous urethra: While urethral strictures can occur after TURP, they are less common than bladder neck stenosis.

 

Option C. Stricture of the bulb of the urethra: Similar to membranous urethra strictures, these are not as frequent as bladder neck stenosis post-TURP.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bladder neck stenosis is the most common cause of delayed urinary obstructive symptoms after TURP.

questions.text: You are working as an ER physician, and a patient with a laceration has just been brought in. You decide to use the interrupted suturing technique to close the wound. As you prepare to suture, you recall that the angle of needle placement is crucial for optimal wound closure. What is the correct angle of needle placement for interrupted suturing technique? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 90 degrees

 

This is the correct angle because inserting the needle perpendicular to the skin (at a 90-degree angle) ensures optimal tissue eversion and approximation of the wound edges. It allows for consistent depth and distance from the wound edge on both the entry and exit points of the needle, which is crucial for the interrupted suturing technique to effectively close the wound.

 

Educational Objective:

 

To properly execute interrupted sutures, it is recommended that the needle is inserted and exited the skin at a right angle (90 degrees). It is important to rotate the needle through the tissue to prevent unnecessary enlargement of the needle hole. The distance between the entry point of the suture and the edge of the wound should be nearly equal to the depth of tissue that is being sutured. Additionally, it is advised to leave a distance that is twice this measurement between two consecutive sutures.

choices.text: Incontinence when patient lies down and coughs

questions.text: A 37-year-old male comes with lower urinary tract symptoms (LUTS). Which of the following is not a typical presenting LUTS? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Incontinence during intercourse

 

While urinary incontinence during intercourse can occur, it is not considered a typical lower urinary tract symptom (LUTS). LUTS typically encompasses symptoms related to storage and voiding of urine. Incontinence during intercourse might be related to other causes, including psychological factors, or specific conditions impacting the pelvic floor, but it's not a routine symptom when discussing LUTS.

 

Incontinence during sexual activity is not considered a lower urinary tract symptom (LUTS).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sudden urge to urinate: This symptom is known as urgency and is a common lower urinary tract symptom. It is the sudden and strong desire to urinate, which can be difficult to delay.

 

Option B. Incontinence while asleep: This is referred to as nocturnal enuresis or bedwetting. It is a type of urinary incontinence where the patient involuntarily releases urine during sleep. This can be a symptom associated with a variety of conditions, including bladder issues, sleep disorders, or even psychological factors.

 

Option C. Incontinence when a patient lies down and coughs: This is known as stress incontinence. It occurs when physical movement or activity, such as coughing, sneezing, running, or heavy lifting, puts pressure (stress) on the bladder, causing unintentional urine leakage. It's often due to weakened pelvic floor muscles.

 

Educational Objective:

 

LUTS can be divided into three categories: storage, voiding, and post-micturitional.

 

Storage LUTS involves the failure of the bladder to act as a urine reservoir, leading to symptoms such as increased frequency of voiding, nocturia, urgency, and urge incontinence.

 

Voiding LUTS is commonly seen in bladder outlet obstruction and includes symptoms such as hesitancy, reduced stream, and straining.

 

Post-micturitional LUTS, also caused by bladder outlet obstruction, includes symptoms such as incomplete emptying and post-micturition dribble. Other symptoms of LUTS include stress incontinence, nocturnal enuresis, and strangury.

questions.text: M3 incisional hernia refers to: (AIIMS NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Umbilical

 

According to the European Hernia Society classification, M3 incisional hernia refers to umbilical hernia.

 

M=Midline, L=Lateral

 

M1: defect up to 3 cm below xiphoid

 

M3: Defect within 3 cm of umbilicus (above or below)

 

M5: Defect up to 3 cm above pubis

 

M2: Defects between M1 and M3

 

M4: Defects between M3 and M5.

questions.text: A 32-year-old lady presents with mobile breast lump which feels like a mouse in breast. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Fibroadenoma

 

A fibroadenoma, often referred to as a "breast mouse," is a benign breast tumor commonly seen in young women between the ages of 16-25. It is characterized by a painless, slowly growing, solitary mobile lump that feels rubbery and can easily move under the skin. This mobility is why it is described as feeling like a "mouse" in the breast.

 

Fibroadenoma:

 

  • Commonality: A benign breast tumor commonly seen in young women.
  • Features: Described as rubbery and mobile under the skin, hence the term "breast mouse."
  • Age Group: Typically affects young women between 16-25 years of age.
  • Diagnosis Fit: Given the patient's age and the description of the lump, fibroadenoma is the most likely diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Phyllodes tumor:

 

  • Nature: Rare breast tumors that can be benign, borderline, or malignant.
  • Growth: They tend to grow rapidly and can become quite large.
  • Age Group: They typically occur in women after the age of 40.
  • Distinguishing Feature: Rapid growth and potential to become large differentiate it from a fibroadenoma.

 

Option C. Invasive ductal carcinoma:

 

  • Nature: The most common type of breast cancer.
  • Presentation: Begins in the ducts and invades nearby tissues in the breast.
  • Mobility: Less likely to be as mobile or rubbery as a fibroadenoma.
  • Age Group: While it can occur in younger women, the mobility and description of the lump make this less likely.

 

Option D. Breast abscess:

 

  • Nature: A pocket of pus due to bacterial infection.
  • Symptoms: Associated with inflammation, redness, warmth, and tenderness.
  • Presentation: Would not be described as mobile or rubbery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fibroadenomas are common, benign breast tumors in young women, characterized by a mobile, rubbery lump that can easily move under the skin, often described as feeling like a "mouse" in the breast.

choices.text: Insertion of wide bore needle in the 5th intercostal space (ICS)

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the emergency department after a motor vehicle accident. On examination, he is noted to have subcutaneous emphysema and decreased breath sounds on the right side. His vital signs are unstable. What is the immediate management for this patient?  (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Insertion of wide bore needle in the 5th intercostal space (ICS)

 

  • The clinical scenario of no air entry on the right side and unstable vitals suggests tension pneumothorax.
  • Tension pneumothorax is a life-threatening condition where air accumulates in the pleural space and cannot escape, leading to increased intrathoracic pressure.
  •  This pressure can shift the mediastinum, compromise venous return to the heart, and result in hypotension or shock.
  • Immediate needle decompression or needle thoracostomy is necessary, which involves inserting a wide-bore needle in the 5th ICS anterior to the mid-axillary line to relieve the trapped air and stabilize the patient.
  • The definitive management is tube thoracostomy or chest tube insertion in the 5th ICS in the triangle of safety.
  • The clinical findings suggest a tension pneumothorax. An immediate decompression is needed to prevent circulatory collapse by allowing trapped air to escape, which can stabilize the patient until a chest tube can be placed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. IV fluids for resuscitation: While fluid resuscitation is vital in the management of trauma patients, the priority in this scenario, given the clinical findings suggestive of tension pneumothorax, is to relieve the trapped air. While IV fluids can support the circulatory system, they won't address the primary problem, which is the tension pneumothorax. The priority in trauma management follows the Airway -> Breathing -> Circulation (ABC) protocol.

 

Option C. Intubation and positive pressure ventilation: Intubation and positive pressure ventilation can be dangerous in a patient with tension pneumothorax. Positive pressure ventilation can exacerbate the tension pneumothorax by forcing more air into the pleural space, which can lead to rapid cardiovascular collapse. Addressing the tension pneumothorax with needle decompression or chest tube insertion should be prioritized before considering intubation.

 

Option D. e-FAST (extended Focused Assessment with Sonography in Trauma): While e-FAST is a valuable tool in the trauma setting to quickly evaluate for the presence of free fluid (e.g., blood) in the peritoneal, pericardial, or pleural spaces, it may not be the immediate choice when a patient presents with clear signs and symptoms of a tension pneumothorax and is hemodynamically unstable. Immediate intervention to relieve the tension is essential, and while ultrasound can confirm the presence of pneumothorax, in an unstable patient, clinical judgment and prompt action are crucial.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In cases of suspected tension pneumothorax, immediate needle decompression in the 5th intercostal space is the priority to relieve trapped air and stabilize the patient before further interventions.

questions.text: A team of emergency responders has been called to the scene of a bomb blast in a crowded city center. Upon arrival, they find multiple casualties with various injuries, including blast injuries. In a blast injury, which of the following organs is least vulnerable to the blast wave? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Liver

 

Explanation:

 

In the context of blast injuries, the liver is considered the least vulnerable to the direct effects of the blast wave due to its solid and dense nature. The primary blast wave from an explosion affects air-filled and delicate structures more significantly than dense, solid organs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. GI tract: The GI tract, especially the hollow parts, is susceptible to blast injuries due to the presence of air. Typical injuries include subserosal hemorrhage and perforation of the intestines.

 

Option B. Lungs: The lungs are highly vulnerable to blast injuries because they are air-filled and delicate. Blast waves can cause severe pulmonary barotrauma, leading to conditions such as pneumothorax, hemothorax, and pulmonary contusion.

 

Option D. Ear drum: The eardrum is extremely sensitive to the pressure changes caused by a blast wave. It is a thin membrane that can easily rupture in an explosion, making it one of the most commonly injured organs in such scenarios.

 

Educational Objective:
