In a blast injury, the liver is the least vulnerable organ to the primary blast wave compared to the GI tract, lungs, and eardrum, which are more susceptible due to their air-filled nature and delicate structures.

choices.text: To give oral antibiotics since the given accumulation is normal
To re-explore the wound and insert a T-tube

questions.text: A patient underwent laparoscopic cholecystectomy. He was discharged after removing the drain tube on the first postoperative day. On day three, the patient returned to the hospital and was febrile. On ultrasound examination, there was a 5 x 5 cm collection in the subhepatic space. Next best step is? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Insert pigtail catheter for drainage

 

The given clinical scenario is suggestive of a bile duct injury following laparoscopic cholecystectomy.

 

The next best step after imaging would be to control inflammation by

 

  • Drainage of fluid collection (Pigtail insertion and drainage) and
  • Administration of broad-spectrum antibiotics

 

This is the most appropriate next step in managing a subhepatic collection. A pigtail catheter is inserted percutaneously under imaging guidance to drain the collection. This helps in both diagnosing and treating any infection or abscess that may have developed after the surgery. It allows for drainage of the accumulated fluid and may be accompanied by sending the drained fluid for culture and sensitivity testing. This step is less invasive than re-exploration and allows for targeted management of the collection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. To give oral antibiotics since the given accumulation is normal: While antibiotics may be considered in some postoperative cases, the presence of a collection along with fever suggests an infection or abscess, making antibiotics alone an inadequate treatment.

 

Option B. To re-explore the wound and insert a T-tube: Re-exploration of the surgical wound and insertion of a T-tube is a more invasive approach and is not the first-line option for managing a postoperative collection.

 

Option D. ERCP (Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography): ERCP is typically used to evaluate and treat conditions of the bile ducts and pancreatic ducts and is not the primary intervention for managing a postoperative collection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bile duct injury

 

  • Usually manifests in the postoperative period

 

Clinical features

 

  • Fever
  • Increasing abdominal pain
  • Jaundice
  • Bile leakage from an incision

 

Diagnosis

 

Imaging: Ultrasonography

 

  • To assess for a fluid collection and to evaluate the biliary tree

 

Treatment Strategy

 

  • Control of infection, limiting inflammation
  • Percutaneous drainage of periportal fluid collections
  • Parenteral antibiotics
  • Clear and thorough delineation of entire biliary anatomy
  • Magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography (MRCP)
  • Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP), especially if cystic-duct stump leak is suspected
  • Reestablishment of biliary-enteric continuity (surgery)
    1. Tension-free, mucosa-to-mucosa anastomosis
    2. Roux-en-Y hepaticojejunostomy

choices.text: Lateral edge of pectoralis major muscle
Lateral border of latissimus dorsi muscle

questions.text: Which of the following is not a boundary of the triangle of safety for chest tube insertion in a patient with pneumothorax on chest X-ray? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Mid-axillary line

 

The mid-axillary line is not a boundary of the triangle of safety. The triangle of safety is defined by specific anatomical landmarks and includes the lateral edge of the pectoralis major muscle, Latissimus dorse, and the fifth intercostal space inferiorly.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lateral edge of pectoralis major muscle: This is the anterior boundary of the triangle of safety.

 

Option C. Base of axilla: This is a boundary of the triangle of safety. It is an important reference point for chest tube insertion to ensure it is performed safely and effectively.

 

Option D. Lateral border of latissimus dorsi muscle: This is a boundary of the triangle of safety. It helps guide the placement of the chest tube in a safe and appropriate location.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The triangle of safety for chest tube insertion is a surgical landmark used to guide the safe insertion of chest tubes in patients with pneumothorax. The boundaries of the triangle are the lateral edge of the pectoralis major muscle, the lateral border of the latissimus dorsi muscle, and the 5th intercostal space (ICS) inferiorly, at the level of the nipple above and lateral to the pectoralis major muscle. The base of the triangle is formed by the anterior border of the latissimus dorsi muscle and the lateral edge of the serratus anterior muscle at the base of the axilla.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man has a lesion over the face as shown below. He complains of bleeding while itching. The most likely diagnosis is: (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) BCC (Basal cell carcinoma)

 

The given history with the image showing an ulcer over the face with pearly, rolled-out borders points to a diagnosis of basal cell carcinoma.

 

Basal cell carcinoma is the most common type of skin cancer, especially in older individuals with sun exposure. It often appears as a pearly or waxy bump with central depression, which can bleed easily. Itching is also a common symptom associated with BCC.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dermatofibrosarcoma: Dermatofibrosarcoma is a rare, slow-growing soft tissue tumor that typically presents as a painless, raised, flesh-colored or brownish lesion. It does not commonly cause bleeding or itching.

 

 

Option B. Marjolin's Ulcer: Marjolin's ulcer refers to a malignant transformation of a chronic non-healing wound, scar, or ulcer. It is often associated with long-standing inflammation or trauma. While it can present with bleeding, it typically doesn't cause itching as a primary symptom.

 

 

Option D. Naevus: A nevus, commonly known as a mole, is a benign skin lesion. While moles can occasionally be itchy, they do not usually cause bleeding unless they are irritated or traumatized.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Basal cell carcinoma is an epithelial tumor that arises from basal cells layer of epidermis. It is the most common type of skin cancer. Most commonly seen over the face, above the line joining corner of the mouth, and lobule of the ear. Clinically it can present either as nodular or pigmented BCC. Features of nodular BCC are:

 

  1. Small, slowly growing pearly nodule
  2. Tortuous telangiectatic vessels on the surface
  3. Rolled borders
  4. Central crusting

 

The occasional presence of melanin in the nodular variant of BCC (pigmented BCC) may lead to confusion with melanoma.

questions.text: In triage, immediately life-threatening injury is categorized as what color code? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Red

 

In the triage system, which is used to prioritize patients based on the severity of their condition, an immediately life-threatening injury is classified under the Red color code. This indicates that the patient requires immediate medical attention to prevent death or severe complications. The Red category is the highest priority in triage, where intervention is needed within 0 to 6 hours.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Green: This color code is used for ambulatory patients with non-life-threatening injuries. These patients are stable and can wait for treatment.

 

Option C. Yellow: The Yellow category is for urgent cases where intervention is required within 6 to 24 hours. While these patients need prompt attention, their condition is not as immediately critical as those in the Red category.

 

Option D. Black: The Black category is reserved for patients who are either deceased or moribund (those who are unlikely to survive). This represents the lowest priority in triage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a triage situation, an immediately life-threatening injury is classified under the Red color code, indicating the need for urgent medical intervention.

questions.text: What sign on day 2 would indicate a need for surgery in a patient who was conservatively managed in the ICU after grade 3 splenic trauma?  (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pneumoperitoneum

 

The presence of pneumoperitoneum on imaging would indicate a need for laparotomy as it suggests visceral perforation, which can lead to secondary peritonitis. Conservative management is usually recommended for splenic trauma, and surgical management is reserved for cases of hemodynamic instability or failure to respond to conservative management. Splenic angiography and embolization are also used for non-surgical management. The severity of splenic injury is graded by the AST spleen injury scale, and abdominal CT with intravenous contrast is the preferred investigation. A drop of 1g% of hemoglobin may be a physiological finding, and would not warrant a surgery.

 

Extraperitoneal bladder rupture can be managed with a urinary catheter, while distended gall bladder is a normal finding if patient has been nil per oral.

 

Grades of splenic trauma based on the American Association for the Surgery of Trauma (AAST) spleen injury scale:

 

 

Pneumoperitoneum, the presence of air in the abdominal cavity, is a concerning sign and typically indicates a perforation of the gastrointestinal tract or another abdominal organ. In a patient with grade 3 splenic trauma, the development of pneumoperitoneum suggests a concomitant hollow viscous perforation and would likely necessitate surgery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hemoglobin falls from 11g% to 10g%: A drop in hemoglobin levels can be indicative of ongoing bleeding but may not be an immediate indication for surgery. It would typically be monitored closely, and the need for surgery would depend on the rate of decline and the overall clinical condition of the patient. Typically, a decline by >2g% Hb is suggestive of active bleed and warrants further management.

 

Option B. Extraperitoneal bladder rupture: While extraperitoneal bladder rupture is a serious condition, it is not directly related to splenic trauma. Its management involves keeping a per urethral Foleys and allowing the rupture to heal.

 

Option D. Distended Gall bladder: This is a normal physiological finding and does not mandate surgery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pneumoperitoneum is the most concerning sign in a patient with grade 3 splenic trauma and would indicate a need for surgery, as it suggests a perforation.

questions.text: According to European hernia society classification (EHS), hernia labelled as PL2 implies? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Primary indirect

 

The European Hernia Society (EHS) classification for groin hernias includes a designation based on the location and whether the hernia is primary or recurrent. 

 

Refers to a primary hernia occurring laterally to the inferior epigastric vessels, which protrudes through the deep inguinal ring. According to the EHS classification, a primary indirect hernia located in the lateral region with defect size 2 finger breadths (3 cm) is labelled as PL2.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Primary direct: Refers to a primary hernia occurring medially to the inferior epigastric vessels, typically in Hesselbach's triangle. It is labelled as “PM”. 2 refers to size of defect as 2 finger breadths (3 cm).

 

Option C. Recurrent direct: Would refer to a recurrence of a hernia in the same place as a previous direct hernia repair.

 

Option D. Recurrent indirect: Would refer to a recurrence of a hernia in the same place as a previous indirect hernia repair.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

According to the EHS classification, a hernia labeled as PL2 refers to a primary indirect inguinal hernia that is having a defect of size 2 finger breadths (3 cm).

questions.text: Most important prognostic factor for Ca Breast is: (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Axillary lymph node status

 

Positive axillary lymph node involvement usually indicates a higher chance of recurrence and a poorer prognosis compared to no lymph node involvement. The number of affected lymph nodes also plays a crucial role in staging the cancer, which directly impacts treatment options and outcomes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Size of the tumor: Generally, the larger the tumor, the worse the prognosis because a larger tumor size often correlates with a more advanced stage of cancer. Tumor size is considered when staging breast cancer, with larger tumors often requiring more aggressive treatment.

 

Option C. Distant metastasis: The presence of distant metastases (stage IV breast cancer) generally indicates a much poorer prognosis because it suggests that the cancer is more aggressive and widespread.

 

Option D. Hormonal status: The hormonal status of the tumor (estrogen receptor (ER) and progesterone receptor (PR) positive or negative) influences both the prognosis and the treatment options. Hormone receptor-positive tumors are often less aggressive and more likely to respond to hormone therapy compared to hormone receptor-negative tumors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

While all these factors are important in assessing the prognosis of breast cancer, the status of the axillary lymph nodes is traditionally considered a key indicator due to its implications for the spread of the disease within the body and potential treatment strategies.

questions.text: A 3-month-old child was brought with complaints of umbilical discharge. Abdominal examination was otherwise normal except for the below finding. The next step of management is: (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) USG Abdomen

 

The given image is that of a congenital umbilical anomaly with an apparent discharging sinus. The given clinical scenario is suggestive of embryonal umbilical anomalies such as patent urachus, urachal cyst, and vitelline cyst (resulting from the persistence of omphalomesenteric duct). The next best step in the management of this case is USG abdomen to diagnose if the anomaly is cystic, fibrous, or of fistula.

 

Ultrasonography (USG) of the abdomen is a safe and non-invasive imaging technique commonly used to evaluate abdominal conditions in pediatric patients. It is particularly useful for assessing the umbilical region and identifying any abnormalities that may be causing the umbilical discharge. USG provides real-time imaging and can help in diagnosing conditions such as umbilical granulomas, urachal abnormalities, or other underlying issues.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. MRI Abdomen: MRI (Magnetic Resonance Imaging) of the abdomen is a valuable diagnostic tool for various abdominal conditions. However, in the case of a 3-month-old child with umbilical discharge, an ultrasound (USG) is typically the initial imaging modality of choice. MRI is generally reserved for more complex or specific cases.

 

Option C. СЕСТ: CECT may be done after USG if further information was desired.

 

Option D. Exploratory laparotomy: Performing an exploratory laparotomy as the initial step in a 3-month-old child with umbilical discharge and an otherwise normal abdominal examination would be overly aggressive and not indicated.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Omphalomesenteric duct abnormalities:

 

  • Vitello intestinal duct or omphalomesenteric duct is the connection between yolk sac and the midgut during embryonic life, which eventually gets obliterated.
  • The persistence of the vitellointestinal duct can lead to various abnormalities according to the part of the duct that is persistent.
  • Persistence of the proximal intestinal end of the duct leads to Meckel's diverticula.
  • Persistence of the distal end near umbilicus leads to umbilical sinus, likely to be the case here.
  • Fully patent vitellointestinal duct can lead to enterocutaneous fistula.

questions.text: What could be the possible diagnosis of a 35-year-old male patient with a history of hypertension and multiple episodes of hematuria and loin pain, whose elder brother passed away due to stroke at the age of 40 and whose ultrasound abdomen is shown below? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease

 

  • The clinical scenario and the ultrasound image provided suggest the diagnosis of Autosomal Dominant Polycystic Kidney Disease (ADPKD).
  • ADPKD is an inherited disorder characterized by the presence of multiple cysts in the kidneys. Over time, these cysts can enlarge and decrease the functioning of the kidneys, leading to kidney failure.
  • Besides renal symptoms, patients with ADPKD can have other complications, such as cerebral aneurysms (which can rupture leading to strokes), liver cysts, and cardiac valvular diseases.
  • The combination of multiple episodes of hematuria, hypertension, familial history, and the ultrasound findings make this diagnosis the most likely.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Renal cell carcinoma: Renal cell carcinoma (RCC) is the most common type of kidney cancer in adults. It originates from the proximal convoluted tubule of the nephron. It may present with hematuria, pain in the flank or loin area, and a palpable abdominal mass. However, the familial context, with the brother's early death from a stroke, doesn't typically fit with the presentation of RCC. RCC occurs in an elderly age group.

 

Option C. Tuberculosis of the kidney: Tuberculosis (TB) can affect the kidneys, usually as a secondary site from pulmonary TB. This can lead to a chronic inflammatory response. Kidney TB might present with sterile pyuria (white blood cells in urine without bacterial growth), hematuria, and even systemic symptoms of TB like fever, weight loss, and night sweats. The clinical scenario provided doesn't specifically lean toward this diagnosis.

 

Option D. Autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease (ARPKD): ARPKD is another inherited form of polycystic kidney disease. However, it's different from ADPKD in that it presents much earlier, usually in childhood or infancy. Symptoms in ARPKD are typically severe and can include kidney failure and liver problems at a young age.

 

  • Given the combination of clinical symptoms, family history, and ultrasound findings, the most probable diagnosis in this scenario is option B, Autosomal Dominant Polycystic Kidney Disease (ADPKD).

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Autosomal Dominant Polycystic Kidney Disease (ADPKD) is an inherited disorder characterized by the presence of multiple cysts in the kidneys, leading to kidney failure, hypertension, and a higher risk of cerebral aneurysms, making it crucial to consider family history and typical ultrasound findings in the diagnosis.

choices.text: Excellent prognosis is associated with this condition.
Nuclear characteristics are used for identification.
Fine needle aspiration cytology (FAC) is not diagnostic.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient presents with a midline swelling in the neck. Upon examination, cervical node enlargement is also observed. Histopathological analysis of the lesion reveals the following findings Identify the false statement of the following?  (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Fine needle aspiration cytology (FAC) is not diagnostic.

 

  • The histopathological findings provided are indicative of papillary carcinoma of the thyroid, which includes features such as papillary formation with a fibrovascular stalk, distinct orphan Annie nuclei, and psammoma bodies.
  • Fine needle aspiration cytology is actually a common and reliable diagnostic method for thyroid nodules, including papillary carcinoma.
  • By extracting cells from the thyroid nodule using a fine needle and examining them under a microscope, the presence of characteristic features of papillary carcinoma can be identified.
  •  Thus, the statement suggesting that FNAC is not diagnostic is false

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Excellent prognosis is associated with this condition: This statement refers to the typical prognosis of papillary carcinoma of the thyroid. Papillary carcinoma, although malignant, is often slow-growing. When detected early and treated appropriately, patients generally have an excellent prognosis with a high survival rate.

 

Option B. It spreads via lymphatics: While papillary carcinoma often spreads via the lymphatics to regional lymph nodes (leading to cervical node enlargement, as seen in the patient), it typically does so at a slow rate. It's important to note that even when there is lymph node involvement, the prognosis still remains relatively favorable compared to other types of thyroid cancers.

 

Option C. Nuclear characteristics are used for identification: The nuclear features of papillary thyroid carcinoma are characteristic and aid in its identification. One such feature is the "orphan Annie eye" nuclei, which are large, empty-appearing nuclei. Other characteristics, like psammoma bodies, can also be present.

 

  • Given the context and the provided image findings indicative of papillary carcinoma of the thyroid, FNAC is indeed diagnostic for this condition. Hence, option D is the false statement among the ones provided.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Fine needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) is a reliable and commonly used diagnostic method for thyroid nodules, including papillary carcinoma, as it can identify characteristic histopathological features.

questions.text: Identify the breast condition shown in the image below? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Mondor’s Disease

 

Mondor's disease is a rare condition characterized by superficial thrombophlebitis of the subcutaneous veins, typically in the breast or chest wall, but it can occur in other parts of the body as well.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Paget's disease: Paget's disease is an insitu lesion of nipple which presents with nipple destruction.

 

Option C. Zuska's disease: Zuska's disease, also known as chronic periductal mastitis is characterized by slit like nipple retraction after repeated inflammation of lactiferous ducts seen in smoker females.

 

Option D. Tietze syndrome: Tietze syndrome is a rare inflammatory condition that affects the cartilage of the ribs and sternum, causing pain and swelling in the affected area. The exact cause of Tietze syndrome is unknown, but it may be related to trauma, infection, or underlying autoimmune or inflammatory disorders. Symptoms may include pain, swelling, tenderness, and redness over the affected area. Treatment options may include nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), corticosteroids, and physical therapy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The clinical presentation of Mondor's disease includes pain, tenderness, and redness over the affected area, along with a palpable cord-like structure that corresponds to the thrombosed vein.
  • The diagnosis of Mondor's disease is made by physical examination.
  • Treatment for Mondor's disease includes restriction of arm movements, nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), warm compresses, and compression garments to alleviate pain and inflammation.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most frequent presentation of an abdominal desmoid tumor? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Abdominal mass

 

The most common presentation of abdominal desmoid tumor is as an abdominal mass.

 

Abdominal mass is the most common presentation of abdominal desmoid tumors. These tumors are characterized by the development of firm, palpable masses in the abdominal wall or other abdominal structures. This is the hallmark sign of these tumors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Abdominal pain: While abdominal pain can be a symptom of abdominal desmoid tumors, it is not the most frequent presentation. These tumors often manifest as painless masses in the abdominal area.

 

Option C. Fever: Fever is generally not a primary symptom of abdominal desmoid tumors. These tumors are primarily associated with the formation of masses rather than systemic symptoms like fever.

 

Option D. Rectal prolapse: Rectal prolapse is not a common presentation of abdominal desmoid tumors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

An abdominal desmoid tumor is a tumor that arises from fibro-aponeurotic tissue in the musculoaponeurotic structures of the abdominal wall, especially below the level of the umbilicus.

 

Desmoid tumors are frequently seen to be associated with Familial Adenomatous Polyposis (FAP) syndrome.

 

It commonly presents as a slow-growing mass and tends to infiltrate muscle in the immediate area. Eventually, it can undergo a myxomatous change and then shows an increase in size more rapidly.

 

The investigation of choice for desmoid tumor is MRI. Biopsy with immunohistochemistry can help in establishing the diagnosis. The tumors typically stain positive for

 

  • 3-catenin
  • Actin and
  • Vimentin.

 

It stains negative for cytokeratin and S-100.

 

  • Treatment includes wide excision with a margin clearance of 2.5cm to avoid recurrence. It is a completely unencapsulated fibroma and is hard to cut. The defect then requires repair using mesh to prevent hernia in the future.
  • Radiotherapy alone is an acceptable treatment option for patients with unresectable desmoid tumors
  • Prognosis is good, with no metastasis or sarcomatous change. Although they lack metastatic potential, they can be multifocal as well as locally aggressive and invasive, with a high propensity for recurrence.

choices.text: Transurethral resection of the bladder tumour

questions.text: An adult male patient in his 60s presented to the outpatient department with a complaint of haematuria. Upon examination, a 2x2 cm bladder mass was observed, which was diagnosed as a low-grade transitional cell carcinoma. What is the recommended course of action for this patient? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Transurethral resection of the bladder tumour

 

For this patient diagnosed with bladder carcinoma, transurethral resection of bladder tumor (TURBT) is the most beneficial treatment option among the given choices. Based on the available evidence, there is no indication of muscle invasion or advanced cancer, suggesting that the most probable pathological stage is pTa - low grade non-muscle invasive cancer, for which TURBT followed by intravesical chemotherapy is the recommended treatment. TURBT is performed to pathologically stage the tumor and determine the appropriate course of treatment. Intravesical therapy using chemotherapy or immunotherapy is administered after TURBT to eradicate any residual cancer cells in the bladder lining, but it is not effective against cancers that have spread to muscle layers.

 

This is the correct answer. TURBT is a standard initial procedure for diagnosing and treating visible tumors, especially for low-grade, noninvasive disease. It involves removing the tumor from the bladder wall via the urethra. The stage of the bladder cancer can be determined by examining the sample removed during a TURBT, which aids in further treatment decisions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Resection with ileal conduit: This is a more invasive surgery typically used for muscle invasive bladder cancers (radical cystectomy). An ileal conduit is a urinary diversion technique where urine is redirected through a piece of the intestine and out to a stoma on the abdomen.

 

Option C. Partial cystectomy with bladder reconstruction: This involves removing a part of the bladder affected by cancer. It's reserved for select patients where the tumor is localized and not near the urethral or ureteral openings. It might not be the first line of treatment for a 2x2 cm low-grade tumor.

 

Option D. Neo-adjuvant chemotherapy: This refers to chemotherapy given before a primary treatment in advanced cancers. In the case of bladder cancer, neo-adjuvant chemotherapy might be used before a surgery to shrink the tumor size or improve outcomes. However, for a low-grade, small tumor, it is not typically the first line of treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Non-muscle invasive bladder tumors (pTa/pT1): TUR-BT + Intravesical chemotherapy

 

Muscle invasive (pT2/pT3 and some pT4): Radical cystectomy + Ileal conduit

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient with squamous cell carcinoma of the neck undergoes radical neck dissection. Which of the following structures is typically spared during this procedure? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Digastric muscle

 

Radical neck dissection spares the digastric muscle.

 

  • The digastric muscle is typically spared during a radical neck dissection. This muscle is important for several functions, including swallowing and jaw movement.
  • Preservation of the digastric muscle helps maintain normal swallowing and chewing abilities, which is essential for a patient's quality of life postoperatively.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A radical neck dissection is a surgical procedure that involves the removal of lymph nodes level 1 to 5, ipsilateral submandibular gland and tail of parotid, as well as other structures in the neck such as the sternocleidomastoid muscle, internal jugular vein, and spinal accessory nerve.

 

In modified radical neck dissections, some structures may be spared, such as the internal jugular vein, sternocleidomastoid muscle or the spinal accessory nerve.

questions.text: In a solid organ transplantation, which organ is associated with a higher incidence of rejection? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lungs

 

Lung transplantation is associated with a higher incidence of rejection compared to other solid organ transplants due to the lungs' constant exposure to environmental antigens and their role in gas exchange, which increases the risk of immune-mediated injury.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Intestine: Intestinal transplantation also carries a high risk of rejection, but it is less common than lung rejection and is often associated with complications such as graft-versus-host disease.

 

Option C. Kidney: Kidney transplantation has a relatively lower incidence of rejection compared to lung and intestinal transplants due to the kidney's immunologically privileged status and the availability of effective immunosuppressive medications.

 

Option D. Heart: While heart transplantation can also lead to rejection, it generally has a lower incidence compared to lung transplantation, possibly due to differences in the immune response and the heart's unique anatomical and physiological characteristics.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Lung transplantation is associated with a higher incidence of rejection compared to other solid organ transplants due to the lungs' constant exposure to environmental antigens, emphasizing the need for vigilant monitoring and immunosuppressive therapy in lung transplant recipients.

questions.text: What could be the most probable diagnosis for a 26-year-old woman who was brought to the ER at Hospital after a car accident, with a stable blood pressure, a GCS score of 3, and a normal non-contrast CT scan? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Diffuse axonal injury

 

The patient's clinical presentation suggests the possibility of diffuse axonal injury, which occurs when the brain experiences shearing forces, often from rotational acceleration within the skull. This can result in damage to the subcortical parasagittal white matter, cerebellum, fornix, and internal and external capsule, leading to disruption of axons and microvasculature.

 

 Automobile accidents are the most common cause of diffuse axonal injury, and patients often remain unconscious from the moment of impact until death. Multiple focal lesions with a characteristic distribution are typical of diffuse axonal injury, and CT scans may appear normal. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), particularly susceptibility-weighted imaging (SWI), is the preferred imaging modality for assessing suspected diffuse axonal injury, and can reveal small regions of susceptibility artifact or hemorrhage. Subdural hemorrhage, extradural hemorrhage, and cerebral contusion are other potential traumatic brain injuries that can present with different imaging features and may require different treatments.

 

Diffuse axonal injury (DAI) is a type of traumatic brain injury that results from the shearing forces during rapid deceleration or rotational head trauma. It can cause profound neurological impairment, even with a seemingly normal CT scan early on. A GCS score of 3 is indicative of severe brain injury, and DAI is a common cause of such a presentation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Subdural hemorrhage: Subdural hemorrhage is associated with bleeding between the brain and its outermost covering (the dura mater). While it can result from head trauma, it typically presents with altered mental status, neurological deficits, or focal symptoms. A GCS score of 3 and a normal non-contrast CT scan make this diagnosis less likely.

 

Option B. Extradural hemorrhage: It can lead to rapid neurological deterioration, often with a lucid interval after the injury. A normal non-contrast CT scan is inconsistent with an acute extradural hemorrhage.

 

Option D. Cerebral contusion: Cerebral contusions are focal brain injuries characterized by bruising of the brain tissue. They can occur in head trauma and may present with neurological deficits or focal symptoms. However, a normal non-contrast CT scan would typically not rule out a cerebral contusion if it's a small or subtle contusion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The patient's presentation with a GCS score of 3 and a normal non-contrast CT scan, the most probable diagnosis is diffuse axonal injury (option C), which can result in severe neurological impairment despite a normal initial CT scan.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child came with complaints of pain over the right lower quadrant and lower back pain. On examination, he had pain over the right side of the hip on passive extension along with a mass in the right lumbar region pointing towards the groin. What is the most likely diagnosis? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Psoas abscess

 

The given clinical finding of pain on hip extension is “psoas sign” which is seen in inflammation of psoas like abscess or appendicitis. However, presence of mass in right lumbar makes psoas abscess more likely.

 

Psoas abscess is an infection that occurs in the psoas muscle, which is located in the lower back and can extend into the right lower quadrant. It can cause lower back pain, hip pain on passive extension, and the presence of a mass in the lumbar region, making it a likely diagnosis based on the symptoms described.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pyelonephritis: Pyelonephritis is an infection of the kidneys and typically presents with symptoms such as fever, flank pain, and urinary symptoms. While it can cause lower back pain, it doesn't typically result in a palpable mass in the lumbar region.

 

Option C. Appendicitis: Appendicitis usually presents with pain in the right lower quadrant, but it doesn't typically involve lower back pain or the presence of a palpable mass in the lumbar region.

 

Option D. Torsion of right undescended testis: Testicular torsion is a condition involving the twisting of the spermatic cord, which leads to severe testicular pain and swelling. It does not typically cause lower back pain or a palpable mass in the lumbar region.

 

Educational Objective:

 

History of abdominal pain and mass in the right lumbar region, with pain on passive extension of the right hip (psoas sign), points towards the diagnosis of psoas abscess.

 

The history of lower back pain needs to be evaluated with the possibility of tubercular origin to be kept in mind in this patient.

 

Treatment is usually by percutaneous CT-guided drainage and appropriate antibiotic therapy.

questions.text: Identify the size of the given blade used for incision and drainage of a superficial abscess and arteriotomy? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 11

 

The blade shown in the image is number 11 blade used for skin incisions (E.g., Incision and Drainage) and Arteriotomy

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

11 number blade is used In stab incisions needed when lancing an abscess or inserting a chest drain and in skin incisions and arteriotomy

questions.text: What is the site for needle insertion in emergency thoracocentesis? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Upper border of lower rib

 

In emergency thoracocentesis, the needle is inserted along the upper border of the lower rib to avoid injury to the intercostal vessels and nerve, which are located along the lower border of the upper rib.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lower border of lower rib: This option is incorrect because it still risks injuring intercostal vessels and nerves.

 

Option C. Lower border of upper rib: This option is incorrect because the intercostal vessels and nerve are located here, increasing the risk of injury.

 

Option D. Middle of intercostal space: This option is incorrect because it does not provide a clear anatomical landmark, increasing the risk of accidental injury.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For thoracocentesis, always insert the needle along the upper border of the lower rib to avoid damaging the intercostal vessels and nerves located at the lower border of the upper rib.
